body:
Horwich Farrelly adheres to all regulations set by:

  • The SRA Standards and Regulations apply to all individuals who work within law firms in England & Wales.
  • The Law Society of Scotland Rules & Guidance applies to all individuals who work within law firms in Scotland.
  • The Law Society of Northern Ireland Regulations and Standards apply to all individuals who work within law firms in Northern Ireland.
  • The Law Society of Ireland Regulations applies to all individuals who work within law firms in the Republic of Ireland.


A fundamental principle of all of these regulations is to ensure we act in the best interests of our clients. To do this, each regulation contains provisions for conflicts of interest.
title: Horwich Farrelly Aim

body:
A client conflict means any situation where:


  • You owe separate duties to act in the best interests of TWO or more clients, in relation to the same or related matters; and
  • those duties conflict or there is a significant risk they will conflict.


An example of a client conflict at Horwich Farrelly would be if we had accepted instructions in a Recoveries case, but then also accepted an instruction to defend a Credit Hire case in the same matter.

title: Text Title
body:
An own interest conflict is any situation where your duty to act in the best interests of any client in relation to a matter conflict, or there is a significant risk that it may conflict, with your own interests in relation to that or a related matter.


There are no exceptions to this rule


If you become aware of an own interest conflict, please contact the Risk & Compliance team immediately. Compliance@h-f.co.uk

_items.backText: All the clients have given informed consent, given or evidenced in writing, to you acting;
where appropriate, you put in place effective safeguards to protect your clients' confidential information; and
you are satisfied it is reasonable for you to act for all the clients.

_transcript.body:
Video TRANSCRIPT

Confidential vs Disclosure conflict

If we decide to act in a client conflict situation, we are very likely to receive information about one client that is relevant to the other. 


This is a ‘Confidentiality vs. Disclosure Conflict’. Client confidentiality is a fundamental principle of all legal sector regulations we are governed by. This means we need to manage our duty to disclose material information, with our duty to maintain confidentiality. 


Client Confidentiality must be maintained unless: disclosure is required or permitted by law or the clients consent. 


Keeping client information confidential demonstrates our commitment to act in their best interests. It is an obligation that starts as soon as we receive their information, continues throughout the matters life and continues even after a matter or client relationship has ended.


All staff within Horwich Farrelly owe a duty to confidentiality to our clients.


So, because we would be likely to receive confidential information about Client One, which is relevant to Client Two (or vice versa), our duty of confidentiality beats our duty of disclosure. 

This means that we can only act if: we can safeguard Client One’s confidential information, we reasonably believe Client Two is aware of, and understands the relevant issues and gives informed consent.


Either: Client One also gives informed consent and we agree safeguards with them to protect their confidential information; if not possible, we put in place effective safeguards, including information barriers that comply with common law, and it is reasonable to act with safeguards in place.

So, how can we safeguard client information in a client conflict scenario?


There is no one size fits all approach, but we will consider:


  • Ring-fencing fee earners or teams logically.
  • Removing any overlap in the management or supervision of fee earners.
  • Ensuring fee earners understand confidential information responsibilities, including signed statements.
  • Restricting a fee earners access to information.
  • Physical separation of fee earners dealing with each client.
  • Password protecting information.
  • Appointing a manager, partner or the Risk & Compliance team to oversee confidentiality.
  • and ensuring correspondence does not allow inadvertent information sharing.


If we cannot implement adequate safeguards, we MUST refuse to act, even if the clients have given informed consent.

title: Conflict checks text
body:
Conflict checks are mandatory and are initially completed at the New File stage.


Therefore, if we receive a case ‘Nomination’ or an ‘Instruction’ from a client, checks are carried out to decide if we can act for the client or not. 


Our HF policy and guidance documents provide a detailed process on these checks.


  • Conflict of Interest Policy
  • Conflict of Interest Procedure England & Wales 
  • Conflict of Interest Identification & Exceptions

_items.body: If at any time a potential conflict is identified, it will be escalated to the appropriate file holders.
If we cannot accept the instruction, we will write to the client to explain why.

If, after instructions are accepted, there is a material change in circumstances as the matter progresses, for example a change of address or party names, in line with HF policy, Fee Earners must complete further conflict checks on that information.
If a Fee Earner does find potential or an actual conflict of interest they must escalate this to their Head of Department.
If we can no longer continue to act, the client must be notified, in writing, of the reason why.
We risk regulatory sanctions, reputational damage, claims for compensation and loss of client confidence.
